natural solution: When using the distributive property for the first time, we add the product of $x+5$ and $x$ to the product of $x+5$ and 7: \begin{align} (x+5)(x+7) &= (x+5) \cdot x + (x+5) \cdot 7\\ &= x(x+5) + 7(x+5).
\end{align}We use the distributive property again and combine like terms: \begin{align} x(x+5) + 7(x+5) &= x^2 + 5x + 7x+ 35\\ &= \boxed{x^2 + 12x + 35}. \end{align}

fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x + 5"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x + 7"

shows  "R x = P x * Q x"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 \end{align}We use the distributive property again and combine like terms: \begin{align} x(x+5) + 7(x+5) &= x^2 + 5x + 7x+ 35\\ &= \boxed{x^2 + 12x + 35}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x + 5"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x + 7"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. R x = x powr 2 + 12 * x + 35"
shows  "R x = P x * Q x"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find the function R(x) such that R(x) is equal to the product of P(x) and Q(x), where P(x) = x + 5 and Q(x) = x + 7. The final answer is R(x) = x^2 + 12x + 35.
